{{other ships|Alexander Nevsky (ship)}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= [[File:«Александр Невский» в Вилючинске.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption= ''Alexander Nevsky'' in [[Vilyuchinsk]]. }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=Russia |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|Russia|naval}} |Ship name= ''Alexander Nevsky'' |Ship namesake=[[Alexander Nevsky]] |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=[[Sevmash]] |Ship laid down= 19 March 2004 |Ship launched= 6 December 2010 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= 23 December 2013 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honours= |Ship fate= |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class={{sclass2-|Borei|submarine}} |Ship displacement=*{{convert|14720|t|LT|0|lk=out|abbr=on}} surfaced *{{convert|24000|t|LT|0|abbr=on}} submerged |Ship length={{convert|170|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|13.5|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draught={{convert|10|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship hold depth= |Ship decks= |Ship deck clearance= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=*1 × [[OK-650 reactor|OK-650B nuclear reactor]] *1 × AEU steam turbine *1 shaft |Ship speed={{convert|28|kn|lk=in}}<ref name="rusnavy1">{{cite web|url=http://rusnavy.com/news/navy/index.php?ELEMENT_ID=11052 |title=Construction of SSBN Alexander Nevsky will cost RUR 23 bln – shipbuilder |publisher=Rusnavy.com |date=2010-12-13 |accessdate=2012-01-01}}</ref> |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=130 officers and men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*16 × [[Bulava (missile)|Bulava]] [[Submarine-launched ballistic missile|SLBMs]] *6 × [[RPK-2 Viyuga]] cruise missiles ({{convert|21|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} [[torpedo tube]]s) |Ship armour= |Ship notes= }} |}
'''Russian submarine K-550 ''Alexander Nevsky''''' is a [[Russia]]n nuclear [[ballistic missile submarine]] of the fourth generation {{sclass2-|Borei|submarine|4}} (Project 955A). Named after the Russian saint [[Alexander Nevsky]], the submarine was laid down in March 2004 and was first planned to be launched in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rusnavy.com/nowadays/strength/nevsky.htm |title=Alexander Nevsky |publisher=Rusnavy.com |date=2004-03-19 |accessdate=2012-01-01}}</ref> However budgetary problems and repeated failures of the submarines main weapon, the [[Bulava]] [[Submarine-launched ballistic missile|SLBM missile]], pushed the launch date forward. Russian officials have however claimed that the submarine has been completed on time and even ahead of schedule.<ref name="rusnavy1"/>
==Design and description==
The submarine was to have been rolled out from its construction hall on 30 November 2010. This was postponed to December due to bad weather, according to the shipyard's press service.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rusnavy.com/news/navy/index.php?ELEMENT_ID=10943 |title=Withdrawal of SSBN Alexander Nevsky from covered slipway was postponed |publisher=Rusnavy.com |date=2010-11-30 |accessdate=2012-01-01}}</ref> On 2 December 2010 the submarine was rolled out from its construction hall to floating dock<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rusnavy.com/news/navy/index.php?ELEMENT_ID=10963 |title=SSBN Alexander Nevsky was moved to floating dock |publisher=Rusnavy.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-01}}</ref> and would be launched at an unknown future date.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://flot.com/news/navy/index.php?ELEMENT_ID=60179 |title=Путин посетил АПЛ "Александр Невский" |publisher=Flot.com |date=2010-12-14 |accessdate=2012-01-01}}</ref> The submarine was inspected by the Russian [[Prime minister|Prime Minister]], [[Vladimir Putin]] on 13 December 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/mlitary_news/20101213/161759690.html |title=Russian military to receive 1,300 types of weaponry by 2020 | Defense | RIA Novosti |publisher=En.rian.ru |date=2010-12-14 |accessdate=2012-01-01}}</ref> With an estimated cost of 23 billion RUR (~$900 million USD), the new submarine has no significant differences from the lead ship, SSBN {{ship|Russian submarine|Yury Dolgorukiy||2}}.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
On 24 October 2011 the submarine started its sea trials.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://russianforces.org/blog/2011/10/aleksandr_nevskiy_begins_see_t.shtml |title=Aleksandr Nevskiy begins see trials |publisher=Russian strategic nuclear forces |date=24 October 2011 |accessdate=19 October 2014}}</ref> It was planned to launch the first SLBM from ''Alexander Nevsky'' in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rusnavy.com/news/navy/index.php?ELEMENT_ID=13461 |title=SSBN Alexander Nevsky To Launch Bulava No Sooner Than Summer 2012 |publisher=Rusnavy.com |date=2011-10-26 |accessdate=2012-01-01}}</ref> The submarine entered service on 23 December 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rt.com/news/russia-nuclear-submarine-nevsky-613/ |title=Russia’s second next-gen nuclear sub enters service |publisher=RT.com |date=23 December 2013 |accessdate=19 October 2014}}</ref>
==Commissioning and deployment== [[File:RIAN archive 813528 Sevmash shipbuilding facility.jpg|150px|thumb|left|K-550 shortly before rolling out to floating dock]] Russian Defense Minister [[Sergei Shoigu]] attended the launch ceremony at the Sevmash shipyard in the northern city of [[Severodvinsk]].
In November 2013, the Defense Ministry said that delivery of the boat would be delayed until 2014 following the failure of an onboard missile system during sea trials in September. The malfunction was the latest in a string of eight failures of the new Bulava missile – developed for the new Borei-class submarines – out of a total of 19 or 20 launches. The new Borei-class boats are currently incapable of performing their primary role of nuclear deterrence while the Bulava has not yet been cleared for service, a navy command source said on November 1. ''Alexander Nevsky'', with a length of nearly two football fields, can carry sixteen Bulava missiles, each fitted with up to ten independently targetable nuclear warheads. The first ship of the Borei class, {{ship|Russian submarine|Yury Dolgorukiy|K-535|2}}, entered service on 10 January 2013.<ref name="indrus">{{cite web|title=New Russian ballistic missile sub to join fleet |url=http://indrus.in/news/2013/12/17/new_russian_ballistic_missile_sub_to_join_fleet_31705.html |publisher=RIA Novosti |date=17 December 2013 |accessdate=19 October 2014}}</ref>
[[Ballistic missile]] [[submarines]] comprise one leg of Russia’s strategic nuclear triad along with land-based ICBMs and a bomber force. The Borei class is Russia’s first post-Soviet ballistic missile submarine class and will form the mainstay of the strategic submarine fleet, replacing aging {{sclass2-|Typhoon|submarine|5}}, [[Delta-class submarine|Delta-3 and Delta-4]]-class boats. Russia ultimately expects eight of the type to enter service by 2020. Russia plans to build a total of eight Borei submarines by 2020, but it is uncertain how many of these will be in the Northern Fleet and how many in the Pacific Fleet. The first vessel, ''Yury Dolgorukiy'' arrived at its home base in the Northern Fleet in September 2013, while the next two are undergoing final testing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Russia builds huge nuclear missile depot in Severomorsk |url=http://barentsobserver.com/en/security/2013/12/russia-builds-huge-nuclear-missile-depot-severomorsk-13-12 |publisher=Barents Observer |last=Petterson |first=Trude |date=13 December 2013 |accessdate=19 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.navyrecognition.com/index.php/news/defence-news/year-2013-news/december-2013-navy-naval-forces-maritime-industry-technology-security-global-news/1445-russian-navy-commissioned-its-second-borey-class-nuclear-missile-submarine-alexander-nevsky.html |title=Russian Navy commissioned its second Borey-class nuclear missile submarine, Alexander Nevsky |publisher=navyrecognition.com |date=23 December 2013 |accessdate=19 October 2014}}</ref>
''Alexander Nevsky'', the second Borei-class vessel, has been commissioned into the Russian Navy, a Russia’s Defense Ministry source told the TASS news agency on 14 April 2015. The submarine passed all its trials, including the test firing of its [[Bulava (missile)|Bulava]] [[Submarine-launched ballistic missile|SLBMs]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tass.ru/en/russia/789154 |title=Second Russian Borei-class nuclear sub with 16 Bulava missiles combat ready — source |work=TASS |date=14 April 2015 |accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref>
''Alexander Nevsky'' transferred from the Northern Fleet to the Pacific Fleet and arrived in the port of Vilyuchinsk, in the Kamchatka Peninsula on 30 September 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://tass.ru/en/defense/824811 |title=Russian nuclear sub carrying Bulava missiles arrives in Kamchatka |date=30 September 2015 |work=TASS |accessdate=30 September 2015}}</ref>
By 10th October, 2016, K-550 had reached the Russian region of the Sea of Japan. It surfaced near a tiny Russian fishing craft, almost sinking the boat and it's crew of two fishermen. They filmed K-550's surfacing and their video went viral in Russia and made world news.<ref>cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/719595/russia-nuclear-submarine-sea-of-japan-sinks-boat |title=Dramatic moment Russian nuclear submarine almost capsizes fishing boat |date=10 October 2016</ref>
